para.p:
It is a fact that the cumulative distribution function of a random variable is a distribution function and that for any distribution function
F

para.p: We first prove the following lemma about distribution functions. 1 1 footnote 1 Kai Lai Chung, A Course in Probability Theory, third ed., p. 236, Lemma 1; cf. Allan Gut, Probability: A Graduate Course, second ed., p. 358, Lemma 6.1.

Suppose that
F

para.p: On the other hand,

Math.text: absolute-value@((integral _ (open-interval@(- infinity, - Delta) union open-interval@(Delta, infinity)))@(((1 - cosine@(T * x)) / x ^ 2) * (F * (x + a) - G * (x + a)) * differential-d@(x))) less= 2 * M * Delta * (integral _ (open-interval@(- infinity, - Delta) union open-interval@(Delta, infinity)))@(((1 - cosine@(T * x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) = 4 * M * Delta * ((integral _ Delta) ^ infinity)@(((1 - cosine@(T * x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x))

para.p: Thus

Math.text: (integral _ R)@(((1 - cosine@(T * x)) / x ^ 2) * (F * (x + a) - G * (x + a)) * differential-d@(x)) less= (- 2 * M * Delta * ((integral _ 0) ^ Delta)@(((1 - cosine@(T * x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x))) + 4 * M * Delta * ((integral _ Delta) ^ infinity)@(((1 - cosine@(T * x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) = 2 * M * Delta * ((- 3 * ((integral _ 0) ^ Delta)@(((1 - cosine@(T * x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x))) + 2 * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((1 - cosine@(T * x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x))) = 2 * M * Delta * ((- 3 * ((integral _ 0) ^ Delta)@(((1 - cosine@(T * x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x))) + 2 cdot ((pi * T) / 2)) = 2 * M * T * Delta * ((- 3 * ((integral _ 0) ^ (T * Delta))@(((1 - cosine@(x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x))) + pi)

para.p: which yields the claim of the lemma, for the subcase (). ∎

We now prove a lemma that gives an inequality for characteristic functions. 3 3 footnote 3 Kai Lai Chung, A Course in Probability Theory, third ed., p. 237, Lemma 2; Zhengyan Lin and Zhidong Bai, Probability Inequalities, p. 29, Theorem 4.1.a. We remark that because
F
is a distribution function, it makes sense to speak about the measure induced by
F
, and because
G

V G

-

= G

G

Suppose that
F
is a distribution function, that
: G

para.p:
that
G
is differentiable and of bounded variation and that its derivative satisfies

Math.text: M = (supremum _ (x element-of R))@(absolute-value@(G ^ prime * x)) less infinity

Math.text: (integral _ R)@(absolute-value@(F - G) * differential-d@(x)) less infinity

para.p: Write

Math.text: Delta = (1 / (2 * M)) * (supremum _ (x element-of R))@(absolute-value@(F * x - G * x))

para.p:
Take
a
to be the real number that Lemma yields. As

Math.text: ((f * t - g * t) / (- i * t)) * e ^ (- i * t * a) * (T - absolute-value@(t)) = (T - absolute-value@(t)) * (integral _ R)@((F * (x + a) - G * (x + a)) * e ^ (i * t * x) * differential-d@(x))

para.p: we obtain, using Fubini’s theorem,

Math.text: ((integral _ (- T)) ^ T)@(((f * t - g * t) / (- i * t)) * e ^ (- i * t * a) * (T - absolute-value@(t)) * differential-d@(t)) = ((integral _ (- T)) ^ T)@((T - absolute-value@(t)) * (integral _ R)@((F * (x + a) - G * (x + a)) * e ^ (i * t * x) * differential-d@(x)) * differential-d@(t)) = (integral _ R)@((F * (x + a) - G * (x + a)) * ((integral _ (- T)) ^ T)@((T - absolute-value@(t)) * e ^ (i * t * x) * differential-d@(t)) * differential-d@(x)) = 2 * (integral _ R)@((F * (x + a) - G * (x + a)) * ((1 - cosine@(T * x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x))

para.p: Using this with Lemma ,

Math.text: 2 * M * T * Delta * (3 * ((integral _ 0) ^ (T * Delta))@(((1 - cosine@(x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) - pi) less= T * ((integral _ 0) ^ T)@((absolute-value@(f * t - g * t) / t) * differential-d@(t))
2 * M * T * Delta * (3 * ((integral _ 0) ^ (T * Delta))@(((1 - cosine@(x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) - pi)
absent less= T * ((integral _ 0) ^ T)@((absolute-value@(f * t - g * t) / t) * differential-d@(t))

para.p: But

Math.text: 3 * ((integral _ 0) ^ (T * Delta))@(((1 - cosine@(x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) - pi = 3 * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((1 - cosine@(x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) - 3 * ((integral _ (T * Delta)) ^ infinity)@(((1 - cosine@(x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) - pi
3 * ((integral _ 0) ^ (T * Delta))@(((1 - cosine@(x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) - pi
absent = 3 * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((1 - cosine@(x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) - 3 * ((integral _ (T * Delta)) ^ infinity)@(((1 - cosine@(x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) - pi
absent >= 3 * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((1 - cosine@(x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) - 6 * ((integral _ (T * Delta)) ^ infinity)@((1 / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) - pi
absent >= 3 * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((1 - cosine@(x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) - 6 * ((integral _ (T * Delta)) ^ infinity)@((1 / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) - pi
absent = 3 cdot (pi / 2) - 6 / (T * Delta) - pi
absent = 3 cdot (pi / 2) - 6 / (T * Delta) - pi
absent = pi / 2 - 6 / (T * Delta)
absent = pi / 2 - 6 / (T * Delta)

para.p: with which we have

Math.text: 2 * M * T * Delta * (3 * ((integral _ 0) ^ (T * Delta))@(((1 - cosine@(x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) - pi) >= (2 * M * T * Delta) cdot (pi / 2 - 6 / (T * Delta)) = M * T * Delta * pi - 12 * M

para.p: and hence

Math.text: M * T * Delta * pi - 12 * M less= T * ((integral _ 0) ^ T)@((absolute-value@(f * t - g * t) / t) * differential-d@(t))

para.p: i.e.

Math.text: Delta less= 12 / (pi * T) + (1 / (pi * M)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ T)@((absolute-value@(f * t - g * t) / t) * differential-d@(t))

para.p: proving the claim. ∎
